item.title: About Validated Patterns
item.description: Validated Patterns and upstream Community Patterns are a natural progression from reference architectures with additional value. Here is a brief video to explain what patterns are all about:

item.title: Patterns quick start
item.description: Patterns quick start Each pattern can be deployed using the command line. The only requirement is to have git and podman installed.

item.title: Importing a cluster
item.description: Importing a managed cluster Many validated patterns require importing a cluster into a managed group. These groups have specific application sets that will be deployed and managed.

item.title: Infrastructure
item.description: Background Each validated pattern has infrastructure requirements. The majority of the validated patterns will run Red Hat OpenShift while some parts will run directly on Red Hat Enterprise Linux or (RHEL), more likely, a version of RHEL called RHEL for Edge.

item.title: OpenShift General Sizing
item.description: OpenShift General Sizing Recommended node host practices The OpenShift Container Platform node configuration file contains important options. For example, two parameters control the maximum number of pods that can be scheduled to a node: podsPerCore and maxPods.

item.title: Using the Validated Patterns Operator
item.description: About the Validated Patterns Operator You can use the Validated Patterns Operator to install and manage Validated Patterns. Use the Red Hat Hybrid Cloud Console to install the Validated Patterns Operator.

item.title: Workflow
item.description: Workflow These patterns are designed to be composed of multiple components, and for those components to be used in gitops workflows by consumers and contributors.

item.title: Validated Pattern tiers
item.description: Validated Patterns tiers The different tiers of Validated Patterns are designed to facilitate ongoing maintenance, support, and testing effort for a pattern.

item.title: Implementation requirements
item.description: Technical requirements Consider these requirements specific to the implementation of all Validated Patterns and their tiers. The requirements are categorized as follows:

item.title: Validated Patterns - Sandbox tier
item.description: About the Validated Patterns Sandbox tier A pattern categorized under the sandbox tier provides you with an entry point to onboard to the Validated Patterns.

item.title: Validated Patterns - Tested tier
item.description: About the Validated Patterns Tested tier The tested tier provides you with additional collateral and reassurance that the pattern was known to be recently working on at least one recent version of Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform.

item.title: Validated Patterns - Maintained tier
item.description: About the Validated Patterns Maintained tier A pattern categorized under the maintained tier implies that the pattern was known to be functional on all currently supported extended update support (EUS) versions of Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform.

item.title: Testing Artefacts
item.description: Testing artefacts To be represented in the CI dashboard, testers can create a publicly available JSON file (for example, in an AWS bucket) that records the result of the latest test for each combination of pattern, platform, and Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform version.

item.title: Values Files
item.description: About values files Values files are essential for creating a structured and flexible approach to customize settings in applications, services, or validated patterns.

item.title: Secrets
item.description: Infrastructure Background Enterprise applications require security, especially in multi-cluster and multi-site environments. Applications require trust and use certificates and other secrets in order to establish and maintain trust.

item.title: HashiCorp Vault
item.description: Deploying HashiCorp Vault in a validated pattern Prerequisites You have deployed/installed a validated pattern using the instructions provided for that pattern.

item.title: FAQ
item.description: FAQ What is a Validated Pattern? Validated Patterns are collections of applications (in the ArgoCD sense) that demonstrate aspects of hub/edge computing that seem interesting and useful.
